analytic.title: Intertemporal Choice

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Everyday examples and broader implications We face a myriad of choices 24/7. The first might arise early in the morning: Should I hit the snooze button for a few extra minutes of sleep, or get up on time to set out for a productive day working on a book chapter? Later, I might have to decide whether to spend my money on that new fancy gadget or put it into my savings plan, and in the evening, I might have to consider whether small immediate 'pleasures' like smoking or feasting outweigh the greater long-term benefits of good health. Decisions that involve outcomes at different points in time are referred to as inter-temporal choices. Some of these decisions may turn out to be irrelevant, while others may significantly shape our future. Even when the outcomes of our choices are uncertain, our inter-temporal decision-making tendencies, whether long or short term, can significantly affect our lives over time (Kable 2014; Keidel et al. 2021). In such situations, humans and many other animals exhibit a tendency towards myopia. That is, when given the choice, we often lean towards the selection of smaller sooner (SS) over larger later (LL) rewards (Kalenscher and Pennartz 2008). The reasons for this preference may be manifold: the perceived cost of waiting, the more immediate appeal of instant gratification over a larger but delayed reward, and/or the uncertainty associated with future outcomes. Either way, future rewards are discounted in value, referred to as delay or temporal discounting (TD) (Ainslie 1975; Frederick et al. 2002; Mazur and Coe 1987). TD is relevant on the individual level but may also affect societies at large (Frederick et al. 2002; Golsteyn et al. 2014). The question of how much we invest for the future, how much we consider and anticipate future states and circumstances appears crucial to many policy areas, including education, healthcare, retirement planning, energy, and climate change (Ericson and

div.p: . Given the importance and prevalence of intertemporal decisions, it is unsurprising that they have been extensively researched across various academic disciplines, including psychology, cognitive neuroscience, behavioral economics, and public policy (Frederick et al. 2002;Urminsky and Zauberman 2015).

div.head: Testing future reward devaluation in the lab
div.p: In experimental studies, intertemporal choice is often evaluated using pen-and-paper questionnaires (Kirby and Maraković 1996) or computerized tasks e.g. (Peters and Büchel 2009), in which individuals make a series of choices between a smaller reward (e.g., money or food), which can be received sooner and a larger reward associated with a delay (e.g., "Would you prefer 30 $ today or 45 $ in 40 days?"; (Myerson and Green 1995;Weinsztok et al. 2021).

By varying temporal delays and reward amounts, researchers can measure how much an individual discounts reward value over time. Various models and measures exist to quantify this behavior, the most common being a discount rate that describes the steepness in value reduction over time (Scholten et al. 2019) (see methods section).

div.head: Clinical significance of (stable) intertemporal preference
div.p: Inter-temporal preferences are fairly stable within an individual, such that one's discount rate today will likely be relatively stable over time periods ranging from months to years (Bruder et al. 2021;Kirby 2009;Odum 2011;Wagner et al. 2023), with a potential genetic component (Anokhin et al. 2015;MacKillop 2013). TD is associated with numerous health-related behaviors, such as a reduced probability of monitoring blood pressure and cholesterol, texting while driving, seatbelt nonadherence, working out, receiving vaccinations and adhering to medical treatment (Bickel et al. 2019;Bickel 2015). TD is also implicated in various mental disorders (Bickel 2015), in particular disorders along the impulsive-compulsive spectrum such as addictions, making TD a candidate transdiagnostic process (Lempert et al. 2019). Due to its involvement in multiple disorders, this shared behavioral pattern may offer new insights into their common underlying features (Amlung et al. 2019).

div.head: State effects on temporal discounting
div.p: Although TD exhibits considerable trait-like stability on individual levels (Gelino et al. 2024), it is also susceptive to within-subject change (Lempert and Phelps 2016;Lempert et al. 2019), such that several experimental manipulations can lead to short-term changes in TD. These are often seen in experimental settings where trial-specific cues or other manipulations are used to modulate choices within a session, e.g. various kinds of pharmacological agents (e.g. dopaminergic drugs), environmental stimuli and a variety of visual cues (Dixon et al. 2006;Foerde et al. 2016;Lempert and Phelps 2016;Miedl et al. 2014;Mathar et al. 2022b;Mathar et al. 2023a;Wagner et al. 2020;Wagner et al. 2023). We illustrate this literature via three examples, 1) the effects of dopaminergic drugs 2) the effects episodic future thinking and 3) the effects of emotional cues. Dopamine (DA) is implicated in reward processing, cognitive control and action selection. Multiple studies have investigated TD in the context of dopaminergic modulation.

While one highly cited earlier study reported an increase in discounting under L-DOPA (Pine et al. 2010), other studies reported consisted decreases under pharmacologically elevated DA levels (Wagner et al. 2020;Erfanian Abdoust et al. 2024;Smith et al. 2024;Wit 2002) or an absence of effects (Acheson and Wit 2008). Thus, the overall evidence suggests that increasing DA neurotransmission, if anything, likely reduces discounting of delayed rewards.

Episodic future thinking (Peters and Büchel 2010b;Rösch et al. 2022), also referred to as prospection, describes the mental process of imagining or projecting oneself into the future to pre-experience events or situations. TD has been consistently shown to be reduced under conditions of vivid future thinking (Rösch et al. 2022), potentially by increasing the concreteness of an abstract distant future (Lempert et al. 2019). On the neuronal level, this is accompanied by increased activity in pathways associated with the processing of uncertainty, memory and future imagination (Peters and Büchel 2010b;Rösch et al. 2022;Cona et al. 2023).

However, cues about occurring events could also carry-over incidental emotions associated with these events which in turn might affect TD (Liu et al. 2013). Kim and Zauberman 2013; Wilson and Daly 2014). However, more recent work has begun to question the universality and magnitude of these effects (Mathar et al. 2023a;Simmank et al. 2015). Studies have raised also doubt regarding previously proposed mechanisms, such as upregulated neuronal reward- (Knauth et al. 2023) or autonomic arousal systems (Knauth and Peters 2022), which were thought to promote myopic behaviors, such that additional research is needed to capture underlying drivers of emotional or affective stimuli in above-mentioned decision-making contexts.

Taken together, a better understanding of state-effects is crucial to identify and understand situational conditions that might exacerbate short-sighted (impulsive) behaviors. This is especially relevant for psychiatric disorders like substance-related or behavioral addictions. For example, field studies have shown that TD is substantially elevated when individuals suffering from disordered gambling are exposed to gambling venues (Dixon et al. 2006;Wagner et al. 2022). Such cue exposure is often associated with both subjective (Wagner et al. 2022) and psychophysiological cue-reactivity responses, craving (urge for consumption), and an increased relapse probability during abstinence (Robinson and Berridge 1993;Vafaie and Kober 2022).

div.head: Training and intervention effects
div.p: While state-effects are important (see previous section), several attempts have been made to achieve longer-lasting changes in TD behavior. For example, EFT can also be structured as a training program, where participants engage in regular sessions of future-oriented thinking (Stein et al. 2016;Sze et al. 2017;Hollis-Hansen et al. 2019). This training aims to fundamentally restructure cognitive processes related to future planning and delay gratification.

Working memory training may also improve TD. For example, Bickel et al. (2011) showed that, following a working memory training, discount rates were significantly reduced in individuals undergoing treatment for stimulant use. Similar results were observed by Felton et al. (2019), who examined working memory training in at-risk-individuals recruited from a community center serving low income and homeless individuals. Whether such interventions can lead to enduring changes in the baseline level of reward devaluation, thus influencing traitlike aspects of TD is an active area of research.

div.head: Methods
div.p: For any psychological construct to be useful, adequate methods and/or models are essential for construct quantification. Intertemporal choice can be quantified using a variety of approaches, including model-agnostic approaches, and model-based approaches that specify underlying computational mechanisms. We will start with more straightforward methods and then move on to more recent developments in computational modeling. Readers already familiar with the subject may therefore wish to skip the following more introductory paragraphs.

div.head: Model-agnostic measures
div.p: One simple but straightforward method is to examine choice proportions of smaller sooner (SS) or larger later (LL) rewards:
Here, P(LL) is the proportion of LL choice, n(LL) is the number of times the LL option was selected, and n(SS) is the number of times the SS option was chosen.

This metric provides a normalized value that allows for comparisons across different participants, groups or conditions. One participant may select the LL reward in 80% of trials, wherease another only does so in 20% of trials (Wagner et al. 2022). However, this metric does not offer any insights into how the perceived value of rewards decreases over time, such as if this decrease follows a linear trend or any other form. It also does not formulate any data generating process that might provide further insights into human cognition.

The area under the curve (AUC) provides a measure of an individual's overall level of TD across the range of delays investigated in a study (Myerson et al. 2001). AUC computation involves two steps. The first step is the computation of so-called indifference points, separately for each delay. An indifference point is the point of subjective equivalence in value between SS and LL rewards, which can be obtained via logistic regression. Consider a scenario with a delay of 12 days, where the immediate SS reward is $20 and the LL rewards range from $21 to $25 (e.g. Figure 1A). The logistic function models the probability of selecting the LL reward as

, where x is the LL amount, where c is the slope of the sigmoid. Choices are coded as 0 when the SS is chosen and 1 when the LL is chosen (see the red and blue dots as examples for two different participants in Figure 1A). Here, the indifference point corresponds to the amount x where P(LL)=0.5 (the participant is equally likely to choose SS or LL). The indifference point can thus be obtained by setting P(LL) to 0.5, and solving for x:

This yields the point of subjective equivalence. Having identified the indifference point for each delay, these points can be connected to form an empirical discounting curve ( Figure 1B), reflecting how a participant's valuation of the LL reward changes over time. To yield a normalized measure that ranges between 0 and 1, the indifference points and delays are normalized relative to their maximum values. The AUC then constitutes the area under the normalized empirical discounting curve, which is computed by computed by summing the shaded trapezoids in Figure 1B (Myerson et al. 2001). The blue function, with its shallower slope, indicates noisier decision-making, i.e. this participant´s choices are inconsistent, and preferences seem to switch non-systematically at the $21, $22, and $23 LL values. However, both participants ID points are nearly identical B, Multiple connected indifference points each for a different delay. Note, to get a normalized AUC the x-(delay) and y-axis (subjective value) are both normalized. The blue shaded trapezoids are integrated across the whole distance. This area can range between 0 and 1 while areas approximating 0 correspond to steep discounting and areas approximating 1 correspond to shallow discounting.

A larger AUC indicates a lower degree of discounting (less impulsive behavior). Conversely, a smaller AUC reflects a steeper discounting (more impulsive behavior). The AUC can be used to compare discounting behavior across different groups of participants or across different experimental conditions. However, it makes no assumptions about the functional form of the relationship between value and time, and thus provides a theoretically agnostic way of how value is discounted over time. This model-agnostic nature of the AUC is one of its strengths and a reason why it is still widely used today, despite the availability of more sophisticated methods. However, it is also one of its weaknesses because it does not formulate a process model that allows for prediction and can be tested against empirical data.

div.head: Computational model-based approaches
div.p: Computational models not only fit observed data but can also specify a data-generating process that can be used to predict unobserved data in untested scenarios, allowing the generalizability of specific formulations of the cognitive mechanisms underlying decision-making.

Computational models incorporate theoretical frameworks with testable assumptions and can be adapted or extended based on specific research questions. Recent advances in computational modeling allow for an investigation of the underlying processes with increasing sophistication, thereby providing further explanatory power (Farrell and Lewandowsky 2018).

div.head: Exponential discounting
div.p: Originally conceptualized by Samuelson (1937) within the framework of classical utility theory, modelling of TD has come a long way since the first half of the 20th century. From this early perspective, the utility (value) of a good decreases exponentially over time, such that the subjective value of the LL reward, SV(LL), is modelled as an exponential function:

Here, k is a discount factor modeling the steepness of the function, D is the delay, and A is the objective magnitude of the LL reward in trial t (Eq. 4). The exponential model assumes that preferences are time consistent, such that adding a constant delay to both the SS and LL options should not change preferences. However, human and animal behavior often deviates from this assumption. Humans often show a decreasing rate of discounting with increasing delay, contradicting the assumptions of the exponential model, leading to preference reversals (Green and Myerson 1996;Mazur and Biondi 2009;McKerchar et al. 2009;Green et al. 1994; and Büchel 2010a).

For example, an individual might prefer an LL reward with a delay of 100 days over an SS reward with a delay of 90 days but switch her preference when the choice is between the same LL reward with a delay of 12 days and an SS reward with a delay of 2 days. This phenomenon dates back to observations in pigeons almost 50 years ago (Ainslie 1974;Ainslie 1975).

div.head: Hyperbolic discounting
div.p: The hyperbolic discounting model, in contrast, suggests the rate of discounting decreases as the delay to a reward increases. That is, the hyperbolic model can account for preference reversals, and is therefore often the standard model in intertemporal choice (Mazur and Coe 1987;Peters and Büchel 2010a). Formally, a simple hyperbolic function describes how value changes as a function of delay (Eq. 5).
Here, A is the objective reward amount of the LL option in trial t. D is the corresponding delay in days and k the hyperbolic discounting rate.

To link Eq. 4 or 5 to the observed choices, a standard logistic action-selection function (softmax) can be applied to model the probability for choosing the LL reward function of the difference between the subjective SS and LL values (Sutton and Barto 2018):

Here, models choice stochasticity (i.e. decision noise relative to the discounting model). As increases, choices become more dependent on the subjective values. As approaches zero, choices become more random relative to the model. Wagner et al., 2022). Note how the red exponential function decays at a constant rate, whereas the hyperbolic function places greater weight on shorter delays compared to longer delays.

div.head: Temporal discounting drift diffusion models
div.p: One problem with the softmax model is that the interpretation of is not always straightforward, as it as it can be interpreted as decision noise (value insensitivity), the tradeoff between exploration (switching between options) and exploitation (sticking to one option) (Sutton and Barto 2018). More generally, is directly related to model fit, such that lower values of generally reflect variance in choices not accounted for by the specific discounting model under consideration. The softmax model also does not account for response times (RTs) or processes that likely modulate RTs (Forstmann et al. 2016). A key feature of sequential sampling models such as the Drift Diffusion Model (DDM) (Ratcliff and Smith 2004), is that they account for both choices and RT distributions. Such models offer a more nuanced approach by decomposing measures into different underlying computational processes, including motor preparation, response bias, information quality and the speed-accuracy trade-off (Forstmann et al. 2016). The DDM assumes decisions to arise from the accumulation of noisy evidence that proceeds until a decision threshold is reached. The foundational work for this process traces back to modeling Brownian motion as random fluctuations of physical particles at specific temperatures (Brown 1828) and was significantly advanced by Norbert Wiener's mathematical exploration of continuous and noisy stochastic processes (Nelson 1967). In 1978, Roger Ratcliff build on these findings to propose the first mathematical diffusion model in psychology capable of predicting RT distributions in the context of memory retrieval (Ratcliff 1978). Interestingly, neural correlates of gradual evidence accumulation in monkeys (Selen et al. 2012;Bichot et al. 2001) and humans (Selen et al. 2012;Shadlen and Kiani 2013) support some of the DDM´s assumptions of how decisions relate to neural activity (Shadlen and Kiani 2013).
In its simplest form, the standard DDM has four parameters:
1. The drift-rate (v), which models the rate of evidence accumulation.
2. The starting point ( ), which models a bias towards either response boundary.
3. The boundary separation (α), which captures the distance between the response boundaries and adjusts the speed-accuracy trade-off, i.e., the amount of evidence needed before a boundary is reached.

4. The non-decision time (τ), which captures aspects of the RT related to stimulus encoding (e.g., sensory processing) and motor preparation. That is, τ reflects all aspects of the RT that are unrelated to the evidence accumulation process (see Figure 3, i.e. the on the x-axis where the blue and red lines begin to diffuse toward the response boundaries).

One recent advancement was the combination of the DDM with standard models, e.g. with reinforcement learning (Pedersen et al. 2017;Fontanesi et al. 2019) (Fontanesi et al. 2019;Chakroun et al. 2023;Pedersen et al. 2017) or TD models (Peters and D'Esposito 2020;Wagner et al. 2020;Rodriguez et al. 2015). Here, the boundaries correspond to the selection of specific options (e.g. SS vs. LL options, see Figure 3 for an illustration) . A choice is made as soon as the accumulated evidence crosses one of the boundaries (Peters and D'Esposito 2020).

However, in its standard form, the evidence accumulation process in the DDM is constant across trials (or varies as a function of experimental condition, e.g. due to differences in stimulus quality in the context of perceptual decision-making see McKoon & Ratcliff, 2008).

The key insights is that decisions should be faster and more accurate as the value difference between options increases. This can be implemented by making the trials-wise drift rate proportional to the value difference between options (as per e.g. Eq. 5, see Eq. 6), combining the strengths of the well-replicated hyperbolic model with the advantages of the DDM. In this combined model the evidence accumulation process is a function of subjective valuedifferences as per the discounting model. Model comparison has revealed that the relationship between RTs and decision conflict is better captured by a non-linear (sigmoid) function (Fontanesi et al. 2019) than a linear function of value differences (Peters and D'Esposito 2020;Wagner et al. 2020;Wagner et al. 2022;Mathar et al. 2022a). That is, in the linear mapping scheme (Pedersen et al. 2017) the trial-wise drift rate vt corresponds to:

In the non-linear mapping scheme (Fontanesi et al.), this scaled difference is additionally passed through a sigmoid: where under standard conditions the participant is confronted with a choice at t=0. The y-axis stretches from the decision-boundary for the SS option to the LL option and represents the evidence space captured by the boundary separation parameter . The starting point parameter captures the starting point and can be interpreted as a bias to either response boundary, notably before any evidence is evaluated. For example, a starting point situated at = 0.5 is equidistantly between both response boundaries (1/2 ) for SS and LL rewards and can be interpreted as no bias for either option. The time between t=0 and starting point of the evidence accumulation process (on the x-axis where both the blue and red walks start to diffuse to the response boundaries) is captured by the non-decision time parameter . This parameter captures the time for stimulus encoding and motor preparation. The blue and red random walks illustrate the trajectories of the drift-rate (v), i.e. accumulating evidence for deciding for the SS or LL reward in a TD task. In this case, the drift rate 0 , is influenced by the linear difference (or sigmoid function) between the trial-wise values of SS and LL options and determines the rate of evidence accumulation as a function of value-differences. Research suggests that the relationship between value differences and drift rate can be modelled as a linear-or sigmoid function and that models using a sigmoid function mostly outperform models using a linear function, as demonstrated in studies by Fontanesi et al. (2019) for reinforcement learning and Peters and D'Esposito (2020) and Wagner et al. (2020;Wagner et al. 2022) for intertemporal choice.

Note that one can easily adapt the other DDM parameters to change as a function of various variables of interest. For instance, we can implement a model where the boundary separation changes as a function of task progression, assuming that participants lower their threshold as they become more experienced with the task (Fontanesi et al. 2019). This combined TD DDM can offer new insights into underlying processes.

For example, one study found that the DA D2 antagonist amisulpride may act differently on different subcomponents of the decision process (Soutschek and Tobler 2023). Another study found that an increase in DA neurotransmission was associated with both a decrease in nondecision time ( ) and a decrease in the discount rate, supporting the idea that DA may impact upon both motor-and non-motor aspects of behavior in TD tasks (Wagner et al. 2020). A study using cue reactivity and erotic stimuli showed that participants' bias ( ) towards SS rewards was increased following cue exposure (Mathar et al. 2023b). Notably, additional modeling work revealed that this bias effect was most pronounced directly after cue exposure, and subsequently declined. Furthermore, the DA precursor tyrosine reduced the boundary separation ( ) (Mathar et al. 2022a), consistent with some DA effects in reinforcement learning (Chakroun et al. 2023).

In summary, the integration of TD models and DDMs not only provides a good account of both choices and RTs, but furthermore allows for a more fine-grained analysis of underlying processes (Miletić et al. 2020). This may be a valuable tool to help understand pharmacological and clinical effects in TD.

div.head: Outlook and future directions
div.p: Extreme degrees of TD (e.g. very steep or very shallow) are associated with several mental disorders, prompting the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) to propose intertemporal choice as a research target within the Research Domain Criteria (RDOC), as part of its longterm goal to better understand the overall processes that go awry in mental illness (Lempert et al. 2019;Lempert and Phelps 2016;Bickel et al. 2019). Steep discounting is consistently linked to behavioral addictions like disordered gambling (Reynolds 2006;Wiehler et al. 2015), substance use disorders (Bickel et al. 2014;Ciccarelli et al. 2019), likely increases with further comorbidities (Moody et al. 2016) and is often detected in major depression disorder (Pulcu et al. 2013;Alloy et al. 2016), ADHD (Jackson and MacKillop 2016) and other mental disorders (Steinglass et al. 2017;Sohn et al. 2014;Lempert et al. 2019).

Here, Bayesian perspectives on intertemporal choice may also provide novel insights. Gershman and Bhui (2020) recently revisted the idea that discounting of future rewards may be linked to the uncertainty associated with future outcomes. In a Bayesian view, the precision with which future rewards can be represented may be inversely related to their delay.

Preferences for SS rewards may therefore arise from increased simulation noise associated with LL rewards (Gershman and Bhui 2020), a finding that fits well with the modulating effects of EFT discussed above (Peters and Büchel 2010b;Brands et al. 2024;Rösch et al. 2022). EFT may counteract this simulation noise by increasing the boundary separation in a TD-DDM (Brands et al. 2024), again highliting the utility of adopting and evidence accumulation perspective.

More generally, several mental disorders are associated with a loss of precision in mental simulation (Friston 2023), i.e. the inability to integrate uncertainty in one's predictions about the future. For instance, depression and anxiety involve uncertainty and negative expectations about the future (Clark et al. 2018). Here, steep discounting might reflect a rational response to anticipated instability in the environment. Similarly, in substance use disorders, high levels of uncertainty, about future rewards may drive individuals toward immediate gratification, akin to a coping mechanism (Dingle et al. 2018;Kober 2014). TD may be related to both internal and external sources of uncertainty (Bulley and Schacter 2020). Unpredictable events in the outside world may favor impulsive choice, as shown in a recent simulation study (Burk and Averbeck 2023). Factoring in both internal uncertainty (e.g. noise in value representations) and external uncertainty (e.g. unpredictable environmental conditions; socioeconomic status) might therefore provide novel insights into links between TD, future simulation(Gershman and Bhui 2020; Bulley and Schacter 2020) and mental disorders.

figure.figDesc: Effects of emotional visual cues on TD have been extensively studied (van den Bergh et al. 2007; Kim and Zauberman 2013; Knauth and Peters 2022; Mathar et al. 2023a; Wilsonand Daly 2014). Here, experimental designs usually involve passive or active visual cue processing before or during TD tasks. Early studies often observed increased TD following presentation of highly arousing erotic cues, in particular in men(van den Bergh et al. 2007;

figure.figDesc: Indifference points and the area under the curve. A, illustrating the fitting of a logistic regression, a specific type of sigmoid function (Eq. 2 & 3), to SS and LL choices within one delay. The red sigmoid function, characterized by a nearly stepwise and steep slope, represents a participant with low decision noise, where a clear preference shift from SS to LL is observed.
